com.hdcookbook.grin
Class ChapterManager

java.lang.Object
  com.hdcookbook.grin.ChapterManager

public class ChapterManager
extends java.lang.Object

A ChapterManager manages the segments in a chapter. "chapter" doesn't exist as a class, but it is in the show file - it's used to set up the right ChapterManager instances. A Director can be implemented using different ChapterManager instances, by putting the state related to a chapter in its ChapterManager. This provides a simple state machine that applications can use to track the coarse-grained state of presentation to the user.

One way this can be used, if you're interested, is with the GoF state pattern. If you do this, you'd have a different subclass for each state. Various behaviors of your xlet could be declared abstract on the common ChapterManager superclass, and you could pass them through the current chapter manager. In this way, you could hook into the state transition that a show gives you.

Many xlets will be to simple to really benefit from this kind of state pattern. In that case, just have one default chapter manager, and never mention a chapter in your show file, and you'll be fine.

Author:
Bill Foote (http://jovial.com)

doKeyEvent

protected boolean doKeyEvent(java.awt.event.KeyEvent e)
Process a keyboard event. This is synchronized by the director. This method must not sleep, because it is called with locks held.

Parameters:
